todos.title: Benefits
todos.body: Usually 30% of salary expense.

todos.title: Real Estate Investors
todos.body: Use them if its easy money but remind them that startups are long-term plays.

todos.title: Pitch
todos.body: Start emotional (character, walk to audience, playful energy, jokes, humility, engage with crowd), go logical (walk towards slide, intense energy, eye contact, serious story, posture, confidence, still movement), finish emotional.  Research comedians, improve, magicians.

todos.title: No debt
todos.body: Preferred to investors, good selling point, after they join they will want you to get LOC.

todos.title: How to explain consulting in a product company
todos.body: Our customers are paying for the development of our product.

todos.title: Opening slide
todos.body: You know what I hear a lot.  It's all about relationships.  Investors, relationships, customers, relationships, talent, relationships, drink tickets, find Hayley.

todos.title: Partner
todos.body: With whomever cafn add strategic value.

todos.title: Cash Flow
todos.body: Will you have enough cash to carry out business model.

todos.title: Channel Partners
todos.body: Who else wants your customer to succeed (chambers, economic development, accelerators, vcs, angels, business innovation centers, salesforce).

todos.title: Generation Gap
todos.body: When pitching to older audiences, wear glasses, dress up, be confident, don't be afraid about silence, anchor points by writing them down, intimidate with you expectations then put a fence around them with attitude.

todos.title: S-1
todos.body: When a company goes public they have to file an S-1 which has a lot of useful info.

todos.title: Balance sheet
todos.body: What you owe, what you own, and what you've put in to date.

todos.title: Main points
todos.body: Use large font so that you can't put 'kind-of' impressive facts.  Four kind of impressive facts are less than one really impressive fact.

todos.title: Eye contact
todos.body: Use it to emphasize key bits of information and set anchors.

todos.title: Tech Council
todos.body: Trade association for small tech companies.

todos.title: Lag time
todos.body: Time from hire to visible effect of that employee.

todos.title: Competition
todos.body: There is no market for what you have if you do not have competition.

todos.title: Raise More
todos.body: Than you think you need.

todos.title: Font
todos.body: Take the oldest person in the room and divide their age by two, don't use white font, for numbers use a plain and boring san-serif in black with white background.

todos.title: Cost of Customers
todos.body: Some software companies spend $1,000 to get each customer.

todos.title: Beware of Self-Funding
todos.body: Some companies that have sold for $100M have only put in $30K.  Don't invest too much of your money.  Set a limit.  Tell other investors you already have significant skin in the game.

todos.title: Pitch Perfect
todos.body: Sell your whole story w/o any missing pieces.  Identify and answer the white elephants in the room.

todos.title: University Library
todos.body: See if they can help you do research.

todos.title: Revenue Projections
todos.body: Science and not an art.  Make sure to backup your projections with hard numbers and historical data.

todos.title: Saas v. Subscription
todos.body: Saas usually has a contract time of 12 months.

todos.title: Personal Guarantees
todos.body: Reward people taking a risk with personal guarantees by giving them warranties (options in company).

todos.title: Zeros
todos.body: Remove zeros and $ signs from financial statements, round to thousand.

todos.title: Intelligence
todos.body: Paying someone a couple bucks to get you the intelligence you need is cheaper than building signals intelligence (Navy Seals).

todos.title: Trust Factor
todos.body: Once you have several major brands you build trust factor and your sales time will decrease.

todos.title: Addition
todos.body: Numbers on tables must add up for the investors that will try to do their own math.

todos.title: Bad words
todos.body: Never say hope, hopefully, I believe, I think'say I know, we have found, it has been proven.

todos.title: Even numbers
todos.body: Never include, they look like guesses.

todos.title: R&D
todos.body: Never ask for R&D money from investors.

todos.title: Employee Contracts
todos.body: Many investors will want to see employee contracts and make sure IP is assigned appropriately.

todos.title: Alternative Investors
todos.body: Look into gov't and military grants, university programs, university entrepreneurship schools/

todos.title: Practicing Pitch
todos.body: Look for local toastmasters clubs or Dale Carnegie Institute to help practice your pitch.

todos.title: Angels
todos.body: Like to herd, need to show others committed, look for 20-25% compounding annual return, patient, willing to take risks, use their own money, Linder, NelNet.  Get in their favor by helping their portfolio companies.  Do two things for them before you ask for one favor.

todos.title: Connectors
todos.body: Investment bankers, accountants, and personal financial advisors know rich people.

todos.title: Risks
todos.body: Identify risks for investors so they know that you know your shit.

todos.title: Attrition
todos.body: How are you going to handle attrition.

todos.title: Skin in The Game
todos.body: Here's the deal.  I've got $50K to add on top of $225 I've already put into the game.  I'm all in but before I throw the next $50K I need $200K to finish my round.

todos.title: Run-rate
todos.body: Growth of revenue from one customer to the next.

todos.title: Taxable
todos.body: Equity is a taxable event if you have a valuation.  Options are not.

todos.title: Valuation
todos.body: Don't overemphasize.  There are many other ways to structure a deal.

todos.title: Referrals
todos.body: Don't leave a meeting without two other people you should talk to.

todos.title: Assumptions
todos.body: Don't forget to list.

todos.title: COGS
todos.body: Does not include sales but includes what it costs to deliver product.

todos.title: Do twice, ask once
todos.body: Do 2-3 things for an investor before you ask for one favor.

todos.title: Market penetration
todos.body: Dell only has 7% of their market.  The more niche audience, the more of the market you can capture.

todos.title: Investor Leads
todos.body: David Graff, Steve Kiene, MacPractice, Parse NE Angels, Clarey, Breck, Linders, NelNet

todos.title: Funding sources
todos.body: Crunchbase, angellist

todos.title: Video
todos.body: Create a 2 min video describing and/or demoing your product.

todos.title: To Investor
todos.body: Can I brainstorm a technology with you that I think could help your portfolio clients.

todos.title: References
todos.body: Build strong references.

todos.title: Sales Cycle
todos.body: Bigger more stodgier industries have much longer sales cycles.

todos.title: First
todos.body: Be careful saying you are the first to do something.  Sometimes the market is not ready for what you are doing.  Showing competition can be helpful.

todos.title: Interview Your Money
todos.body: Ask questions to Angels, don't let them control the conversation or else they will feel superior to you.  Meet prospect investors every 3 months.  Cold calls don't work for VCs or Angel networks,  get an introduction.

todos.title: Volume or Quality
todos.body: Are you going for volume of customers or size/quality of customer.

todos.title: Options Pool
todos.body: 4-5 years vesting, no right until after first year.  Usually pricesd at 10-20% of share prices.  Usually allocate 10-20% of total stock pool for options.

todos.title: Signup for LinkedIn recruiting so they can't see you.
VCs ' 30% compounded return, work with others money, less patient, usually only invest when there is product and traction, average VC invests in a deal for 9.4 years.
